item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Greeny:

[quote]You know, i love how Europe picks at us because we do everything different (which to them means we aren’t doing it right, heh). I think they forget that this country was created to be different than the rest. But now people are trying to change it to be more like Europe which starts the whole conservative-liberal debate etc. And is a prime reason American conservatives are seen as idiots and against anything ‘good’.

Moparisthebest makes a fantastic post, and you come in and say something like that. I really do sometimes wonder if you know the history of your own country Frell. You are fully aware I presume that Europeans built America, through colonisations of various areas. Mainly Spanish and British. Native Americans existed but nearly got wiped out, but this isn’t a history lesson…

Your country was founded by free europeans looking for a better world. As MITB said, freedom of religion being one of the aims. So I come to my final point, why do europeans throw the hate and say you do things wrong? Because of what happened. What your country became, instead of what it could have become. It’s annoying, and it’s not you or your generations fault but you don’t do anything to fix it so many hold you just as accountable as previous generations.

I don’t want America more like Europe. You’re the last remaining superpower. I expect you to be the forefront of mankind. The people who should say “the world is wrong”, and try to change it. Corporate influence over diplomatic discussions ruins that. There’s my beef (I think you American’s say).

The thing to understand is, I think my own country does things in a stupid way but we tell ourselves and each other. The British all hate out government anyway, whereas American’s often show support for theirs, and generally towards anything America is doing (isn’t there a patriot’s act or something? I’m not well read up that). People hate arrogance, people dislike those who feel big about themselves, and America feels big about itself. It’s your biggest downfall, the inability to accept that you could be wrong (as a nation in general, not as individuals).

Again, I’m trying to avoid stereotyping or generalising but it’s incredibly difficult and kind of pointless, because I have nothing against those who don’t fit the stereotypes. It’s just those that do that are so goddamned annoying and fuel these Europe hates America flame wars. cough Frell cough[/quote]
Actually agreed with your post, and alot of people here are very arrogant. What i meant by mine, for instance, would be like the healthcare bill. People think the ones against it here just hate to help people etc. Its little stuff like that that keeps the bickering. Basically im saying we were built to be different, so why make comments about how we do everything different? And yes our country does alot of things wrong, but we have never discussed anything other than wars here. And the main problem with that is when people think we go skipping around starting wars everywhere, and of course in reality we aren’t. Even though it seems like it.

[quote=“Speljohan, post:23, topic:370891”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=466983.msg3415401#msg3415401 date=1291004005]

When it comes to fast food, I think any government has the responsibility to protect it’s citizens from a lifestyle that would be detrimental to their health. A citizen may be ignorant in not grasping the reality of the consequences that such a lifestyle would bring, and it’s the government’s responsibility to compensate for that ignorance by restricting the citizen’s freedom when it comes to practicing such a lifestyle.

Maybe a government should protect children, or mentally handicapped people against things like this. But a full grown, sensible adult should be able to eat what they please. Governments allow smoking, alcohol, countless over-the-counter medications and other things that are ‘detrimental to health’, why should food be any different. Americans don’t want government messing with our rights, period. (and that is the main thing that separates America and the vast majority of the rest of the world)
[/quote]Why do you even want a government? Seems like it is just an obstacle to you.[/quote]
Every citizen has 2 governments pretty much. Our federal government should only do 4 things, none which affect any of us directly. But over the years, shit like social security, welfare, etc has stockpiled into our budget. Our state governments are supposed to be doing everything else, but its slowly being flipped around and people are becoming more angry.

Read full topic

item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

You know, i love how Europe picks at us because we do everything different (which to them means we aren't doing it right, heh). I think they forget that this country was created to be different than the rest. But now people are trying to change it to be more like Europe which starts the whole conservative-liberal debate etc. And is a prime reason American conservatives are seen as idiots and against anything 'good'.

Moparisthebest makes a fantastic post, and you come in and say something like that. I really do sometimes wonder if you know the history of your own country Frell. You are fully aware I presume that Europeans built America, through colonisations of various areas. Mainly Spanish and British. Native Americans existed but nearly got wiped out, but this isn’t a history lesson…

Your country was founded by free europeans looking for a better world. As MITB said, freedom of religion being one of the aims. So I come to my final point, why do europeans throw the hate and say you do things wrong? Because of what happened. What your country became, instead of what it could have become. It’s annoying, and it’s not you or your generations fault but you don’t do anything to fix it so many hold you just as accountable as previous generations.

I don’t want America more like Europe. You’re the last remaining superpower. I expect you to be the forefront of mankind. The people who should say “the world is wrong”, and try to change it. Corporate influence over diplomatic discussions ruins that. There’s my beef (I think you American’s say).

The thing to understand is, I think my own country does things in a stupid way but we tell ourselves and each other. The British all hate out government anyway, whereas American’s often show support for theirs, and generally towards anything America is doing (isn’t there a patriot’s act or something? I’m not well read up that). People hate arrogance, people dislike those who feel big about themselves, and America feels big about itself. It’s your biggest downfall, the inability to accept that you could be wrong (as a nation in general, not as individuals).

Again, I’m trying to avoid stereotyping or generalising but it’s incredibly difficult and kind of pointless, because I have nothing against those who don’t fit the stereotypes. It’s just those that do that are so goddamned annoying and fuel these Europe hates America flame wars. cough Frell cough

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t have anything against the police force, but no matter how well funded or well intentioned, they can’t be everywhere at once. This is why people have the right to defend themselves and should avail themselves of that right if need be.

item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:24, topic:370891”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=466983.msg3415492#msg3415492 date=1291019930]

When it comes to fast food, I think any government has the responsibility to protect it’s citizens from a lifestyle that would be detrimental to their health. A citizen may be ignorant in not grasping the reality of the consequences that such a lifestyle would bring, and it’s the government’s responsibility to compensate for that ignorance by restricting the citizen’s freedom when it comes to practicing such a lifestyle.

Maybe a government should protect children, or mentally handicapped people against things like this. But a full grown, sensible adult should be able to eat what they please. Governments allow smoking, alcohol, countless over-the-counter medications and other things that are ‘detrimental to health’, why should food be any different. Americans don’t want government messing with our rights, period. (and that is the main thing that separates America and the vast majority of the rest of the world)
[/quote]Why do you even want a government? Seems like it is just an obstacle to you.

To do the bare minimum required of a government. Provide security (police, army, fire departments etc), and maintain infrastructure (roads, bridges etc). Maybe I missed a thing or two, but it’s late and that’s all that immediately comes to mind.[/quote]Ok, infrastructure, got it! But security? Considering your earlier posts about gun control, you provide your own “security”, and the police is just an oppressive force?

Read full topic

[/quote]Why do you even want a government? Seems like it is just an obstacle to you.[/quote]

To do the bare minimum required of a government. Provide security (police, army, fire departments etc), and maintain infrastructure (roads, bridges etc). Maybe I missed a thing or two, but it’s late and that’s all that immediately comes to mind.

When it comes to fast food, I think any government has the responsibility to protect it’s citizens from a lifestyle that would be detrimental to their health. Maybe a government should protect children, or mentally handicapped people against things like this. But a full grown, sensible adult should be able to eat what they please. Governments allow smoking, alcohol, countless over-the-counter medications and other things that are ‘detrimental to health’, why should food be any different. Americans don’t want government messing with our rights, period. (and that is the main thing that separates America and the vast majority of the rest of the world)

item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:370891”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=466983.msg3415336#msg3415336 date=1290998268]
Regarding naming a country that starts with U: Do Americans refer to America as just America, or the United States of America?
If I referred to America as America all day long then I wouldn’t have considered United States of America either.
[/quote]
Probably America mostly. But also as the US, the USA, and of course The United States of America.[/quote]
I honestly would have said Uruguay…

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:18, topic:370891”][quote author=Thug-life link=topic=466983.msg3414914#msg3414914 date=1290973603]
If you look around for long enough, and then compile a list of those with stupid answers, delete all the ones that managed to answer correctly and you’ll get similar results.

I didn’t find people to be stupid when I went to America. Now, in general - for some reason, people don’t seem to be as well traveled as people from Europe, New Zealand and Australia, but they mostly weren’t stupid people.

I like to poke fun at things like American cars, and other things from American culture, but the American hate on this forum is getting a little extreme, and kind of undermines any debate that starts up with the US being the main topic, which is a shame.
[/quote]

That’s right. I’ve often watched stuff like this and have no idea where they find these people, I’ve met stupid people in my life, but never this many or with this level of stupidity. I half suspect that some of these people are being stupid on purpose, just to get on TV or something.

I don’t know about your comment about traveling, it depends on how you look at it. I would say Americans generally don’t travel to other countries as much as Europeans, but that’s probably due to America being HUGE compared to all the tiny countries in Europe. For example, a few years ago my brother and I went on a road trip to the Grand Canyon and drove 4044 miles in a week, which is 2022 miles one way, you couldn’t drive that far in England ever without hitting water. I view Europe’s nations as similar to America’s states. There are 50 of them and I can point them all out on a map, in grade school geography we learned all the countries in Europe too, and I’m sure I can point out a fair share of them, but certainly not all, and I bet Europeans couldn’t point out all of our states either. Doesn’t make either one of us stupid, we just live in different regions.

I’ll be the first to admit that America and therefore Americans, aren’t perfect. But no country or people are, nor have they ever been or ever will be. America does a lot of stuff right, and a lot of stuff wrong that needs changed, but this is always the case. I’m very proud to be an American, proud of my countries history and proud to be free. I think maybe this feeling is stronger in America than some other countries because we are a relatively new country, our recent ancestors CHOSE to come here, fought for and created this America. If you live in most of Europe, chances are your family has been there for countless generations, and has chosen to stay there for one reason or another, being more complacent with your government would therefore be in your blood. Americans don’t like taxes, and are continually and always suspicious of government and don’t want government to expand it’s powers, which I believe is a good way to be. Taxes and too much government control (including control over religion) are basically the only reason we separated from Britain, so obviously we still disagree on these types of things.

Religion is another difference, most European countries at one point in their history had a state religion. France Catholics, England Church of England, etc etc. America was founded on freedom of religion, in fact quite a few founding states of the union were founded simply because they couldn’t practice their religion in England. I’m a practicing Catholic who believes in God, but if you aren’t I also support that, just as it’s my right to worship as I see fit, it’s also yours to worship or not. Don’t force your views on me, and I won’t force mine on you.

Lastly, rights. Again this is based on how and why America was formed, by people who felt their rights were being trampled on by foreign governments. We may have a lot of fat people here, but that is because those people CHOOSE to be that way, and our government doesn’t mandate what we can and can’t eat (Australia). From the same freedom a lot of people CHOOSE to be skinny, again, government shouldn’t intervene. Some people here choose to play violent video games, or watch movies everyone may not find appropriate, and it’s not the governments place to tell them they can or can’t (Australia again). Some choose to back up the right to defend themselves with the means to defend themselves, guns, and then others choose not to (England, Australia). Some choose to complain loudly about the government, hold protests, assemblies, and start blogs and forums, that is their right too (China).

To each their own. That would be a good motto for America. That was a long post, but it needed to be said, I feel I’ve explained myself fairly well.[/quote]

You know, i love how Europe picks at us because we do everything different (which to them means we aren’t doing it right, heh). I think they forget that this country was created to be different than the rest. But now people are trying to change it to be more like Europe which starts the whole conservative-liberal debate etc. And is a prime reason American conservatives are seen as idiots and against anything ‘good’.

Thug-life:

the American hate on this forum is getting a little extreme, and kind of undermines any debate that starts up with the US being the main topic, which is a shame.

Exactly what im told by some very smart people on this forum who don’t even step into arguments.

Radeon:

When it comes to fast food, I think any government has the responsibility to protect it’s citizens from a lifestyle that would be detrimental to their health. A citizen may be ignorant in not grasping the reality of the consequences that such a lifestyle would bring, and it’s the government’s responsibility to compensate for that ignorance by restricting the citizen’s freedom when it comes to practicing such a lifestyle.

Toys in happy meals were banned in San Francisco, you only get the toy if you get fruit and milk etc. McDonalds complained because it should be peoples choice. Are you aware of all the changes McDonalds has done in the past few years? Theyve changed alot of stuff because IIRC the FDA told them they need to get to a certain degree of health by 2015.

Read full topic

[quote=“Thug-life, post:10, topic:370891”]If you look around for long enough, and then compile a list of those with stupid answers, delete all the ones that managed to answer correctly and you’ll get similar results.

I didn’t find people to be stupid when I went to America. Now, in general - for some reason, people don’t seem to be as well traveled as people from Europe, New Zealand and Australia, but they mostly weren’t stupid people.

I like to poke fun at things like American cars, and other things from American culture, but the American hate on this forum is getting a little extreme, and kind of undermines any debate that starts up with the US being the main topic, which is a shame.[/quote]

That’s right. I’ve often watched stuff like this and have no idea where they find these people, I’ve met stupid people in my life, but never this many or with this level of stupidity. I half suspect that some of these people are being stupid on purpose, just to get on TV or something.

I don’t know about your comment about traveling, it depends on how you look at it. I would say Americans generally don’t travel to other countries as much as Europeans, but that’s probably due to America being HUGE compared to all the tiny countries in Europe. For example, a few years ago my brother and I went on a road trip to the Grand Canyon and drove 4044 miles in a week, which is 2022 miles one way, you couldn’t drive that far in England ever without hitting water. I view Europe’s nations as similar to America’s states. There are 50 of them and I can point them all out on a map, in grade school geography we learned all the countries in Europe too, and I’m sure I can point out a fair share of them, but certainly not all, and I bet Europeans couldn’t point out all of our states either. Doesn’t make either one of us stupid, we just live in different regions.

I’ll be the first to admit that America and therefore Americans, aren’t perfect. But no country or people are, nor have they ever been or ever will be. America does a lot of stuff right, and a lot of stuff wrong that needs changed, but this is always the case. I’m very proud to be an American, proud of my countries history and proud to be free. I think maybe this feeling is stronger in America than some other countries because we are a relatively new country, our recent ancestors CHOSE to come here, fought for and created this America. If you live in most of Europe, chances are your family has been there for countless generations, and has chosen to stay there for one reason or another, being more complacent with your government would therefore be in your blood. Americans don’t like taxes, and are continually and always suspicious of government and don’t want government to expand it’s powers, which I believe is a good way to be. France Catholics, England Church of England, etc etc. America was founded on freedom of religion, in fact quite a few founding states of the union were founded simply because they couldn’t practice their religion in England. I’m a practicing Catholic who believes in God, but if you aren’t I also support that, just as it’s my right to worship as I see fit, it’s also yours to worship or not. Don’t force your views on me, and I won’t force mine on you.

Lastly, rights. Again this is based on how and why America was formed, by people who felt their rights were being trampled on by foreign governments. We may have a lot of fat people here, but that is because those people CHOOSE to be that way, and our government doesn’t mandate what we can and can’t eat (Australia). From the same freedom a lot of people CHOOSE to be skinny, again, government shouldn’t intervene. Some people here choose to play violent video games, or watch movies everyone may not find appropriate, and it’s not the governments place to tell them they can or can’t (Australia again). Some choose to back up the right to defend themselves with the means to defend themselves, guns, and then others choose not to (England, Australia). Some choose to complain loudly about the government, hold protests, assemblies, and start blogs and forums, that is their right too (China).

To each their own. That would be a good motto for America. That was a long post, but it needed to be said, I feel I’ve explained myself fairly well.

Read full topic

item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah

Either US or America, to recite the entire name would be too much work for us lazy Americans.

item.title: Americans
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Some of you are fucking ridiculous. I’ve met numerous Americans in person, and none of them have given off the vibe that they’re completely stupid. A lot of work and editing goes into videos like that one; they’re made to entertain, so you know that things have been chopped and changed to misrepresent someone.

Case in point: the question about a triangle, which had a big guy say 4 and then a woman say 1. Clearly edited. And besides, as geographically ignorant as Americans may be, maths is the language of the world and I can assure you that geometry is studied universally. :rolleyes:

I had a feeling that it was going to be the Chaser’s skit before clicking the link, and I was right.

Regarding naming a country that starts with U: Do Americans refer to America as just America, or the United States of America?
If I referred to America as America all day long then I wouldn’t have considered United States of America either.

Read full topic

The American interviews Australian one was tragic, not because the people being interviewed were stupid, but because the interviewer was such an idiot - he didn’t prove anything with that. He did it wrong.

It could be done right, but he didn’t do that.

If you look around for long enough, and then compile a list of those with stupid answers, delete all the ones that managed to answer correctly and you’ll get similar results.

[quote=“Sanskrit, post:13, topic:370891”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=466983.msg3414958#msg3414958 date=1290978021]

Thought it was funny. But thats not all of us, but there are alot of idiots and i wont deny it. We only take world history 2 out of the 12 years we’re in school, and we arent near any of those countries. You’d probably get a similar(still better) reply from Australians etc.

Video was funnier because they interviewed rednecks

Radeonsantiamericanmeter++

What is a redneck? What is your ethnicity?
[/quote]

Rednecks are people who usually live in trailerparks and aren’ t very well educated (you can tell by the accent). I think this video is pretty accurate about how stupid some Americans are, but they didn’t show any of the answers of the smarter population, so it was really biased. I knew most of the answers and I am younger than most of the people in that video.

Article making fun of Britain’ s poor population: http://www.thedailymash.co.uk/news/society/britain’s-poor-people-now-beyond-the-pale-20080408855/[/quote]

It’s funny cuz Radeon isn’t British.

item.title: Americans
